head.title: Veins of the Pelvis and Lower Limbs

body.p: Most of the veins that drain the pelvis and lower limbs have the same names as the arteries they accompany. All of these veins empty into the inferior vena cava, which returns the blood to the heart.

p.term: Major Veins of the Pelvis and Lower Limbs

table.title: Major Veins of the Pelvis and Lower Limbs

tr.td: Feet, muscles of the posterior compartment of the lower leg
The posterior tibial vein is formed by the merger of the medial and lateral plantar veins; Receives the fibular vein (peroneal vein)
The dorsalis pedis vein becomes the anterior tibial vein
Ankle joint, knee joint, tibiofibular joint, anterior portion of leg
Paired veins; Accompany the anterior tibial arteries; Merge with the posterior tibial vein at the knee to form the popliteal vein
Knee joint; skin, muscles, and bones of parts of the calf and thigh near the knee joint
Collect blood from the small saphenous veins and tributaries that correspond to popliteal artery branches

The femoral vein is a continuation of the popliteal vein; Collects blood from the deep veins of the thigh (deep femoral veins) and great saphenous veins; Called the external iliac vein when it ascends into the pelvic cavity
Lower limbs, cremaster muscle in males, abdominal wall
The external iliac veins are continuations of the femoral veins; In the pelvis, they merge with the internal iliac veins to form the common iliac veins
In the pelvis, the interior iliac veins merge with the external iliac veins to form the common iliac veins
Formed by the merger of the internal and external iliac vein; The left common iliac vein is much longer than the right; The two common iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava
Medial side of leg and thigh, groin, external genitalia, abdominal wall
- Longest veins in the body - Begin at the dorsal venous arches - The great saphenous vein is often harvested for use as a coronary bypass vessel
- At the knee, the small saphenous veins empty into the popliteal veins
Thick, elastic fibers dominant feature; external elastic lamina well developed
Thick, smooth muscle dominant feature; external thin elastic lamina
Two or three layers of smooth muscle
Thin and diffuse; much sympathetic nerve association
Discontinuous smooth muscle layer; individual smooth muscle cells regulate blood to capillaries
Endothelial cells and basement membrane only
